Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019: Mitochondrial genome architecture as a driver of speciation in parasitic lice
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Most animals have mitochondrial DNA on a single chromosome. However, some species of parasitic lice have their mitochondrial DNA separated onto multiple chromosomes. It is not known how or why such a rare condition is maintained in lice. The fellow seeks to address this knowledge gap by testing whether differences in mitochondrial genome architecture (that is, single vs. multiple chromosomes) are linked to natural selection and speciation, the processes largely responsible for generating biodiversity. To this end, the fellow will rely on museum collections to compare DNA sequences and body measurements of lice species that have multiple mitochondrial chromosomes to those that have a single chromosome. This work will help answer a particularly puzzling question in biology while simultaneously showing a mechanism that generates biodiversity. The project will also include educational components that promote biodiversity among general audiences at both local and national scales.

The fellow will use multiple lines of evidence obtained from museum specimens to specifically address whether fragmented mitochondrial chromosomes act as a buffer to speciation via mito-nuclear incompatibility. First, the fellow will compare phylogenetic diversity, mutation rates, and genomic selection in two groups of avian lice that are known to have different mitochondrial architectures: wing (fragmented chromosomes) and body (single chromosomes) lice from doves. Lower mutation rates but higher diversification, divergence, and selection in body lice would suggest that single mitochondrial chromosomes promote speciation. Second, the fellow will test mutation rates and levels of selection in cryptic species of lice. Cryptic species have indistinguishable morphological differences but are highly divergent genetically. If pairs of cryptic body louse species have inseparable morphology with high genetic divergence and signatures of positive selection, whereas cryptic wing louse species do not, this would again indicate that single chromosomes promote speciation. The fellow will receive extensive training in morphology-based inquiry and genome evolution. This project will also include a component for training Purdue University undergraduate students in molecular/bioinformatic methods. Additionally, results from the work will be incorporated into lesson plans, outreach displays, and educational publications focused on evolution and biodiversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mitochondrial genomes (mitogenomes) in most animals have very consistent structures: 37 genes on a single, circular molecule that is usually between 14,000-17,000 base pairs in length. In humans and model research organisms, deviations from this structure have been associated with aging and various diseases. However, some species of parasitic lice (a type of insect) have fragmented mitogenomes; they possess the same 37 genes, but these genes are separated onto two or more circular fragments of DNA. Very little is known about why this phenomenon exists in lice. This project addressed the question of whether mitogenome fragmentation is related to speciation (the generation of new species) and biodiversity in lice. Specifically, the project involved three main components: 1) determine how prevalent fragmented mitogenomes are in parasitic lice, 2) test for evidence of natural selection associated with mitogenome fragmentation, and 3) test for co-evolution between mitochondrial and nuclear DNA.


For the first component, the fellow assembled mitochondrial genomes from over 30 different species of parasitic lice. Based on this analysis, there was strong evidence that many of these species have fragmented mitogenomes. Other species have the usual single mitogenome. Mapping this information on a phylogenetic tree showed that fragmented mitogenomes evolved from single mitogenomes several times throughout the evolutionary history of parasitic lice. Thus, fragmentation is relatively common and seems to evolve frequently in lice relative to all other animals.


The second component involved using the DNA sequences from mitochondrial protein-coding genes to test for evidence of natural selection in species with fragmented mitogenomes. Specifically, this involved testing for evidence of relaxed selection in these species. Based on other findings from this project, lice with fragmented mitogenomes have a different composition of nucleotides (percentage of A, T, C, and Gs) in their mitochondrial DNA compared to lice with single mitogenomes. Previous research suggests that differences in nucleotide composition in lice is due to relaxed selection, so relaxed selection in fragmented genomes would be consistent with this hypothesis. This is exactly what tests for selection showed – relaxed selection is associated with transitions from single to fragmented mitogenomes in lice. Relaxed selection could indicate there is less of a link between mitochondrial and nuclear genes, which are often closely co-evolved. In turn, this could have an effect on species diversity in lice.


The idea of co-evolution between mitochondrial and nuclear DNA extended into the third major component of the project. To more fully characterize this interaction, it was necessary to compare mitochondrial genes to nuclear genes that code for proteins involved in cellular respiration (called “nuclear OXPHOS genes”). However, high-quality nuclear genomes from different species of lice are needed to compile these OXPHOS genes. Currently, there are only genomes of two species of species, but several more genomes are needed to make comparisons across the diversity of lice. To this end, PacBio and tell-Seq sequencing technology were used to sequence the nuclear genome from an individual louse specimen sampled from a European starling. These types of sequencing approaches are cutting edge technologies, particularly for non-model species that have a small size (and are thus often difficult to obtain high amounts of genetic material from). The louse nuclear genome obtained from these genomic data was very complete, which is on par with other louse genomes that were obtained using multiple louse individuals and different DNA sequencing technology. The approach demonstrated in this project has incredible promise for efficiently sequencing more louse genomes in the near future.


In addition to research outputs, this project resulted in training for several graduate and undergraduate students, development of public outreach curriculum, and dissemination of research findings in multiple forums. Two graduate students received training in bioinformatics, genomics, and molecular evolution. These are becoming increasingly important areas in biology, and it is crucial that graduate and undergraduate students receive hands-on training to become proficient in each area. Two undergraduate students also received experience learning about evolutionary genetics and genomics. After the learning experience, the students were required to present what they learned to a subset of faculty members. Curriculum development involved the design of an interactive display about biodiversity in parasitic lice. The display includes microscope slides (and a microscope) with different species of lice from around the world, as well as an infographic about the importance of biodiversity in both parasites and free-living organisms. The display will be included in public outreach events in the future. Finally, the results from this project were disseminated in two papers at peer-reviewed scientific journals and in oral presentations at three national research conferences. Two additional papers will be submitted to peer-reviewed journals within the next year.
